ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My Chinese improved, and I have gained tremendous amount of knowledge regarding traditional Chinese culture, especially about traditional Chinese families and marriage.

I learned so much Chinese history and culture well beyond the scope of the class readings, as Su Laoshi expanded extensively on the social and political backdrops to each writer and work we read. I also enjoyed engaging with the texts in a detailed and critical way by dissecting imagery and figurative language, historical vocabulary, gender roles, and political allegories--Su Laoshi showed us how details as small as a character's name or an unusual contrast between two adjectives could reveal an entire thread of social critiques or the birth of a new avant-garde literary movement in China. The homework and essay assignments all helped improve my formal Chinese writing skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of this course is it is very organized and fun to take. I think it would be great if there are more feedback provided on our work.

My vocabulary improved immensely thanks to the listening/writing quizzes--it may seem tedious to write out characters in an age where you can just type in pinyin, but I found that Su Laoshi's classic pen-and-paper method is truly the most effective way to memorize new terms and grammar. The textbook format is very straightforward and easy to follow, and I appreciate that Su Laoshi is able to anticipate which terms are unfamiliar to L5 students and include them at the exact right places in the text--this layout not only helped me read the texts without having to flip back and forth in a dictionary, but it also helped me tie specific vocabulary terms to vibrant plots and imageries as mnemonic devices. The grammar and content homework in the textbook is quite time-consuming, but Su Laoshi is usually very lenient on deadlines, so they shouldn't pose a significant source of stress. Finally, Su Laoshi is highly specific and very clear in his feedback to the class on assignments, meaning you can never make the same mistake twice, and you'll always be improving as long as you take his advice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students who want to learn about Chinese culture, because this class uses the readings to discuss many different fields of the culture.

Yes, absolutely. Even if you aren't necessarily interested in Chinese literature, just taking the class for the sake of learning from Su Laoshi's deep well of knowledge and life experience would be worth it. Even if you don't go into class already captivated by Chinese literature, you will definitely leave class wanting to read and learn more. Sometimes, the workload comes off as tough love, but it's balanced out by Su Laoshi's generosity with grading and deadlines.
